answer_html: More precisely, that means there must exist at least one function \(f\): A \(\rightarrow\) B such that the function is injective and surjective; that is, for each element a of the set A there exists a unique element b in the set B such that \(f(a)\) = b (that condition is the injectivity) AND for each element b of the B there exists a unique element a in the set A such that \(f(a)\) = b (and this is the condition for surjectivity).
answer_latex:
More precisely, that means there must exist at least one function $f$:
\emph{A} $\rightarrow$ \emph{B} such that the function is injective and surjective;
that is, for each element \emph{a} of the set \emph{A} there exists a
unique element \emph{b} in the set \emph{B} such that $f(a)$ =
\emph{b} (that condition is the injectivity) AND for each element
\emph{b} of the \emph{B} there exists a unique element \emph{a} in the
set \emph{A} such that $f(a)$ = \emph{b} (and this is the condition
for surjectivity).
hints_html: An example is not a definition. But it sure helps to have some examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to define.
hints_latex:
An example is \textbf{not} a definition. But it sure helps to have some
examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to
define.
hints_raw: An example is '''not''' a definition. But it sure helps to have some examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to define.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Two sets A and B are said to have the same cardinality if there exists a bijection from one set to the other.

More precisely, that means there must exist at least one function \(f\): A \(\rightarrow\) B such that the function is injective and surjective; that is, for each element a of the set A there exists a unique element b in the set B such that \(f(a)\) = b (that condition is the injectivity) AND for each element b of the B there exists a unique element a in the set A such that \(f(a)\) = b (and this is the condition for surjectivity).
sols_latex:
Two sets \emph{A} and \emph{B} are said to have the same cardinality if
there exists a bijection from one set to the other.

More precisely, that means there must exist at least one function $f$:
\emph{A} $\rightarrow$ \emph{B} such that the function is injective and surjective;
that is, for each element \emph{a} of the set \emph{A} there exists a
unique element \emph{b} in the set \emph{B} such that $f(a)$ =
\emph{b} (that condition is the injectivity) AND for each element
\emph{b} of the \emph{B} there exists a unique element \emph{a} in the
set \emph{A} such that $f(a)$ = \emph{b} (and this is the condition
for surjectivity).
sols_raw:
Two sets ''A'' and ''B'' are said to have the same cardinality if there exists a bijection from one set to the other.

More precisely, that means there must exist at least one function &fnof;: ''A'' &rarr; ''B'' such that the function is injective and surjective; that is, for each element ''a'' of the set ''A'' there exists a unique element ''b'' in the set ''B'' such that &fnof;(''a'') = ''b'' (that condition is the injectivity) AND for each element ''b'' of the ''B'' there exists a unique element ''a'' in the set ''A'' such that &fnof;(''a'') = ''b'' (and this is the condition for surjectivity).
statement_html: Define what it means for two sets A and B to have the same cardinality.
statement_latex:
Define what it means for two sets \emph{A} and \emph{B} to have the same
cardinality.
statement_raw: Define what it means for two sets ''A'' and ''B'' to have the same cardinality.
